message: There are some flies teeming on the basket. Apart from some rotten meat and vegetables, there does not seem to be anything valuable inside it.
Under all the rotten food there is a long vine all rolled up. It might be useful, so you decide to take it.
You have already plundered the basket.
You find a hole next to a large rock which seems decently nailed on the floor.

replies.text: Tie the vine to the rock.

Haha. This rock looks like my brother Andor. 
I think I've been on the trail too long... I'm going crazy.

message: Once tied, you strongly pull the improvised rope a copule of times against you. It seems resistant enough to help you climbing down the hole.
Attention villagers: Climbing the mountain has been prohibited due to the recent, tragic events. All mountain patrol crews have been disbanded until further notice.
This must be the remains of some imprudent villager who ventured into the mountain despite the warnings. There are signs of a former camp down the mountain.
You see a corpse, much more decomposed than the one you saw in the hillside, and wrapped up in cobweb. What kind of spider would be able to do such a thing?
A second after you break the cobweb, a bunch of small spiders emerge from the corpse. Some of them climb up your arm and manage to bite you before you shake it and get rid of them.

replies.text: Ugh, great. This one had nothing but ugly spiders.
*looking at the corpse*. Poor man, no match for a couple of arachnids... Rest in peace.

message: Nothing interesting here.
Yet another corpse in the same state as the previous one. One of its tibiae seems fractured.
That is certainly not a wound one of these spiders would cause. There's something strange about all this.
You have already looked at this corpse.
This one is the most decayed of all corpses you saw here. Who are these people?

replies.text: Rest in peace, whoever you were. (Leave it be)
*looking at the dead body* Well, I don't think you need your belongings anymore, right? (Plunder the corpse)

message: YOU! We will pursue you for your crimes!
There's certainly nothing but rotten flesh and bones here.
You throw another quick glance at the blood-stained chair. What an horrible scene.
One of the chairs is moved apart from the rest. Numerous dried blood stains are all over it and over a rope. Someone has been tortured here, no doubt about it.
After several minutes of careful but fruitless search, you decide to take one of the ropes that were presumably used by the torturer.

The very few rays of light that barely illuminate this small tunnel get lost in the inmense darkness of this hole. There's neither ropes nor vines that could help you to go down. Furthermore, you can neither figure out how far away the floor is.
Assured of not being prepared to explore whatever would be down there, you decide to avoid the hole and continue your way to the other shore.
From this place you can spot a numerous couple of slopes the current follows loyally. Further away, the stream ends abruptly in what seems to be a waterfall and after that, just darkness.
It is definitely not a good idea to keep going this way without any reason.

There's nothing written here anymore. The wood is rotten, dried and cracked, the borders of the sign are eroded and a dense layer of grime covers its top. It must have been ages since someone put it here.
Damn it, kid! Watch your step. You almost ran me over.

replies.text: Sorry sir, I am on a rush.
Watch my step? You'd better watch your tongue.

message: Uhm, what's the matter?

replies.text: As I said, I don't have time to talk. I need to report something important.
Nothing of your concern. I must go inside.
I have discovered something shady inside the mountain.

message: Not only blind but bad-mannered too! You remind me of myself when I was younger. I was not blind, though, ha ha ha!
I'll leave it be. But tell me, why that urge of going inside so quickly?

replies.text: I don't trust you, so nothing.
I have information related to the recent disappearings.

message: I see. But keep in mind that no one inside there will pay attention to you, whatever you say.
Have you? *He gets closer*
Look, I personally don't think that telling the guards is a good choice.
Ok, kid. Do it, I'll wait here for your return, heh.
This is no place for kids.

replies.text: I will report your bad-manners to your chief.
I might have some information about the recent disappearings.

message: Yeah, we already know about the gornauds.
Look, I have more important things to do than babysitting a kid, ok?

replies.text: Hmpf, when the gornauds get the village surrounded I'll be the one babysitting you all.

message: Yes. They seem to be learning from every attack and their numbers are increasing.

replies.text: Will you hear what I have to say then?

message: Of course you can. Go back home and let me and the rest do our job. Understood?

replies.text: Whatever, you won't stand up after a Gornaud blow.

message: The guard is mumbling something to itself and seems not to be either feeling your presence or ignoring you completely.
In front of you, some guys seem to be hearing carefully or rather gingerly a charismatic voice.
I am a very reasonable man, but the problems between this village and Blackwater settlement have delayed the tax collection of this region.
Taxes are the solid pillar that maintain our and your lands. Other villages will rightly complain if we continue to be as amiable as before.
With all due respect, general, the problems our village is passing through are wider and more complex than a simple disagreement with the people of Blackwater Settlement.

Yes...The mines are closed due to lack of workers. We are scarce of resources and isolated from the rest of the world because of the collapsed tunnels. On the other hand, monster attacks are increasing in frequency and proximity to the village.

Yeah, yeah. I'm aware of the current situation. 

Ok, first of all, I will leave some of my men here to reinforce the village. They are reliable...Most of them at least.
I will travel to Blackwater settlement, and in the meanwhile, you must think about this offer:
Feygard will consider that the villagers of Prim will have fullfilled and exceeded their duties with the kingdom if, and only if Prim leaves the full managment of the mines to the capital.
What?! You can't...!

HOW YOU DARE TO INTERRUPT MY GENERAL?! 

[Guards of both sides get more and more tensed up]
Calm down you all. Where's all that temperance of you, soldiers of the glorious Feygard?
I am leaving now. You have a few days to think about it, but I'm afraid this is the best solution. Feygard will also take charge of the rebuilding and cleaning tasks of the tunnel if you accept.
...We will truly consider your proposal. Best of luck in your travel, general.
I'm on duty, youngster. Go play somewhere else.

replies.text: Hah! Good one. Go buy a better sword, rookie.
How does it feel that a kid killed more gornauds than you?

message: Bah! I said I AM ON DUTY!
Beware kid, it's dangerous out there.

replies.text: Of course. I am sometimes out there.

message: Ha ha! Hilarious, but seriously be careful out there.

replies.text: Ok, sir. Thank you for the advice.

message: Hey kid! Can you do me a favor?

replies.text: Have you seen my brother Andor? He looks similar to me.

message: Yes, can you... Eh? Your brother? No idea. Is he from this village?

replies.text: No, he is not. But thanks anyway.
No...But tell me about the favor you were talking before.

message: Well. Do you mind bringing me some food? I have not eaten anything decent since we arrived to this village.

replies.text: I don't have food, but here's 50 gold.

message: Oh, looks good! Thank you, kid. Here's something shiny I've found.

replies.text: Oh! Thank you. Good luck in your duties.

message: Cheese! It is rare to taste cheese out of home. In exchange, take this strawberries I gathered in the Stoutford outskirts. They are fresh, but I don't like its taste.

replies.text: So you already had food? I traveled long to bring you that cheese. Goodbye, hmpf.
Thank you. Have a good day.

message: Well. It is said that money doesn't bring happiness but gets it closer. Thank you.

replies.text: Anything for the glory of Feygard!
50 gold is a bargain to me. No worries.

message: Here, here! I won't be in shape for much time if you keep bringing me this. Take a couple of these "Izthiel" claws. They might keep you alive in case of exterme neccessity.

replies.text: I am grateful, sir. Have a nice day.
Don't stand at the same place the full beat if you want to get in shape. Bye.
I'll keep that in mind. Thank you.

message: It's good to see vigorous youngsters wandering around here and there. You sure could become a soldier of Feygard.

replies.text: And ending like you, guarding the outskirts of a village? Zero action jobs aren't my type.
Sorry, but I am a follower of the Shadow.

message: And good-mannered too! Keep going like this.

replies.text: Thank you. Have a good day, sir.
I will. How is the patrol going?

message: The Shadow? Probably your parents inculcated those ideas to you. Let me tell you they are wrong. Followers of the shadow only promote chaos and anarchy.

replies.text: Chaos and anarchy? Have you ever met with a priest of the shadow?
Hmmm, probably your parents inculcated those ideas to you, but I won't try to change your mind. Bye.

message: Oh yes. Good speakers with poison in their tongues. They conspire with the savages of the South against our righteous lord, just for putting some order in all the chaos left after the war.

replies.text: Uh oh, I never saw it that way.
Or maybe just good speakers who don't like their rituals to be banned nonsensically...
Every flock has their black sheeps.

message: Neither your shadow is trustworthy, this is the best advice I can give you.

replies.text: May Shadow not be with you, then.
It'd better be. My shadow knows what I can do with unwanted ghosts.

message: Whatever, kid. My round is ending and I don't like your tone. You will see how I am right when you got older.

replies.text: Yeah, I won't waste my time anymore with a close-minded Feygard soldier. Bye.
I did not want to offend you... Sorry.
Maybe, but I certainly won't see is myself as a Feygard soldier.

message: Maybe you are right...But it's the duty of the shepherd getting rid of those black sheeps.

replies.text: Is your general a good shepherd?
Maybe you are right too. How is the round going?

message: Absolutely. He is the smartest and strongest man I ever had the honor to meet and serve.

replies.text: I bet he won't survive the wyrms.
I think I will leave you and your fanatism.

message: HOW DARE YOU?!
About to end for me. The people of this village is exaggerating. There are not so many monsters, they are just weak.
These gornauds are no match for us, soldiers of the great Feygard.

replies.text: Sure. How many have you killed?

message: Heh, you have a point there, kid.

replies.text: Have you seen anything out of normal?
Do you mind selling me some of your shiny armor? You know, I need protection.

message: Well...I...Actually, I should not be talking with you during my patrol. Leave me now.
Not really. Guard patrolling tends to be a boring work, but someone has to do it.

replies.text: I see. Hope you finish it soon, sir.
Have you find anything...for me to play with?

message: Your protection inside the village is granted by us. A kid like you does not need an armor, but some friends to play with.

replies.text: Tell me some interesting story to tell my friends then. Did something happen during your round?

message: Thank you, kid.
Huh? No. But if you have some gold to spare, I could sell you some bargains I've found during my duties.

replies.text: Sure, let me have a look.
I am not looking for bargains.

message: I might have even some shiny gems...
Out of my sight kid. I'm on duty.
We soldiers of Feygard have come to this lonely place by direct command of General Ortholion, and don't have time to play with a kid.
This is not a good place to talk about this. But trust me, there is much at stake and Prim's situation is only going to get worse. Let me...

OUT OF THE WAY, COMMONERS!

You and the other guy startled and stepped aside. Three man with Feygard distinctions were leaving the hall. You both kept silence.
I will say it only once. No taverns, no exploring, no dramas with those untrained Prim guards and for the glory of our homeland don't pursue any injured monster.
I have a bad feeling about all this. These villagers might hide something. Tell the mountain scouts to wait for me at the tunnel entrance, they will escort me up to Blackwater settlement.
Yes, my general.
The three guys continue their way out of the village, completely ignoring your presence.
*looks nervious*  I told you. Something big is about to happen and I believe it is somehow related with what you've seen up in the mountain.

replies.text: How did they reached this place?
How do you know what I've seen?

message: I presume the same way as you did.

'Cause I've seen you climbing up the mountain side and going down the hole, of course!

I was waiting for your comeback.

replies.text: All of this is getting too shady. I'd better leave.

message: Look, this is not a safe place to talk. Meet me in the Elm mine, west of here, ok?

replies.text: I hope this won't get shadier.

message: Do whatever you want, youngster. But two minds sometimes work better than one, and four eyes better than two...
Ok, I'll be waiting for you there.
Excellent. Try not to raise suspicion.
I'm afraid It will. Farewell.

Psst! Come, come here.

[The voice is coming from the dining-room]
Well, how did it go?

replies.text: No luck, but I heard a tense conversation between a Feygard general and one of the patrol captains.

message: I did see that general leaving. Now his henchmen are patrolling the village entrance.

replies.text: They are up to no good.
It's good to see they are protecting the villagers.

message: Most probably.
I severly doubt they are there just for that.

replies.text: Are you accusing the great soldiers of Feygard of anything? I'd better leave.

message: Hello again my little friend. Here will be safe from prying ears.

replies.text: Care to explain your reasons to be here and stalk me?

message: I definitely saw you by chance. Please, let me explain what happened.

I arrived here several weeks ago for no particular reason. I am part of a family of explorers and travelers, and the story of a ruined tunnel infested by dangerous beasts was something I wanted to see with my own eyes.
The rumours were true. Those gornauds are not natural creatures, they made me have a really bad time.
I managed to reach the other entrance of the tunnel, but with no potions or fresh food I thought it was the end. Luckily, a guy called Lorn rescued me and brought me here.

replies.text: That name seems familiar to me, somehow.

message: Due to my exhaustion, I lied in a bed for days. I could hear the constant noise of the workers chatting, toasting with their mead jugs...

But the day I got up, completely recovered, the first thing I noticed was precisely the absence of those noises. The rooms next to me was dirty and empty. No one was in the dining-room and the mine entrance was closed.
Arghest, the only guy left here pointed me out where the village was, so I decided to go and ask for my savior. Lamentably, he was no longer there.
Some villagers said he and his patrol crew had left three days ago in search of a couple that climbed up the mountain. So I went to the local shop, I got some supplies and...
Are you gonna stop interrupting me?

replies.text: If that makes you finish sooner...

message: Well. After nearly two days of restless searching, I figured out they could have returned, so I started to climb down.
I suppose, if you want to call it like that.
I fell off a cliff on a narrow path of the mountain side and ended up at the same plateau you climbed up, where the corpse was. I could not believe what I was seeing.
Lorn lied next to me, just a few meters of distance. His armor was entirely covered by blood, which was flowing slowly to the ground, out of his body.
There was a campfire, yes. Now I think about it, it could have belonged either to the couple or to the patrol crew.
I didn't dare to go down the hole...

replies.text: Was Lorn dead when you found him?
I found some dead bodies inside.

message: Almost... I put his armor out. His injuries were severe. I tried to cure him using my potions but they weren't strong enough. He died, failing to express his latest thoughts with words.
But everything he couldn't say with words was said by the terrifying glance he threw to that dark hole, just before his last breath.
Yes, I was about to ask you... Continue.

replies.text: The corpses were covered by cobweb, but I could see torture signs.

message: Anything more you can tell me about that place?

replies.text: Give me some time to remind.
The corpses were covered by cobweb. They were probably tortured.

message: Fine, I'll be waiting here.
Tortured you say? That makes no sense!

replies.text: I took some ropes to demonstrate what I saw to the guards...

message: Are you sure?

replies.text: Yes, look at this blood-stained rope.

message: ...Just after witnessing my savior's death I ran away and came back to the village.

replies.text: Did you tell the guards what you saw?
Shame on you! You should have buried him at least.

message: I tried, but they considered it an accident. My constant babbling did not help...

replies.text: Why the guards did not bury their partner?

message: Strange, isn't it? Really, they didn't really seem to care about Lorn, neither the other missing people. It was all monsters' fault and that's all.

replies.text: There's something too shady in all of this.
Guards, lazy as hell in every place I go.

message: You are honestly right, but It's too late to come back...

replies.text: You didn't bury him, but why the guards didn't either?

message: Yes. And that's why I need your help.

replies.text: You should give me a reward just for hearing this whole story.

message: [Ehrenfest stays quiet with his head down]

replies.text: So ... Why the guards did not bring Lorn's remains to the village?

message: Sometimes. heh. But still, something that doesn't fit.

replies.text: Indeed. There's something shady in all of this.

message: [He seems to be completely absorbed by his own monologue]
Hmm, I will try.
Now that everything is told, let's find some answers.
Okay, okay. Let's take a break. We'll talk later.

replies.text: Do you have anything to trade?

message: I'm afraid not.
We must gather information, I am convinced Lorn's death has to do with what you saw down the hole.
You will talk with the villagers, we have to find out what happened to Lorn's partners, about whom we know nothing yet.

replies.text: Sounds boring, but I'll do it.

message: I will ask in the inn about the couple who got lost and whose trace Lorn and his partners followed.

replies.text: I'd complain, but I prefer not to hear your explanation.

message: Excellent. Let's meet again later, best of luck.
$playername, how is it going?

replies.text: You lied to me. There wasn't any missing couple.

message: Don't give up. We'll eventually get some answers.
Lorn? N...No. Why I would know about that?

replies.text: I promise I won't say anything.
I can make you talk one way or another.

message: Alright! I will tell you, but please don't hurt me.

replies.text: Don't worry, hah. But tell me.

message: You promise?

I heard about Lorn's accident, but I didn't believe he fell off the mountain. 
He is the most skilled guy when it comes up to climb up and down the mountain.
They're still missing, but I don't know...

replies.text: Thank you for your honest words.

message: I told you everything I knew, sorry.
Oh, poor Lorn. I heard that he fell off the mountain.

replies.text: People say he was so skilled climbing.

message: No, sorry. I didn't know him much.

replies.text: Thank you. Shadow be with you.

message: Was he? Well, I think he might had bad luck...
You might ask in the Tavern. He was a regular there, like most guards.

replies.text: Thank you. Shadow be with you.

message: Lorn? Nothing, I barely know him, neither his comrades, Dualia and... No idea. \n What's wrong with him?

replies.text: He was killed several days ago.
He had an accident while climbing down the mountain.

message: Oh. I'm sorry. May the shadow guide his way to a better world.

replies.text: Right, uhm...Don't you remember anything about him?

message: Yes, that's why climbing up the mountain is forbidden now.
Uhm, well. I heard Lorn was popular among the children here in Prim because his scary stories about, you know, the monsters.

replies.text: My father probably told me scarier stories. Bye.

message: Lorn's crew accident you say? No idea. They are still missing, officially.
Sorry child, I do not pay attention to the local gossip. Try luck asking someone else.

replies.text: Thank you, Shadow be with you.
What a waste of time, tsch.

message: I have heard about an accident, yes, but I've been very busy lately.
*staring you comptemptuously* I also take various repairing orders, kid. Now get out of my shop.
*sob* Leave me alone...

replies.text: Cheap mead won't make you forget.

message: Th..then buy me an expensive one. Ha, ha.

replies.text: I won't waste my time with you anymore.

message: Lorn t...too? We will all die!
Why? *sob* What have we d...done to deserve this!

replies.text: People say he fell off the mountain side.

message: [The robust guy ducks his head]

replies.text: Anyway, Lorn died by falling off the mountain.

message: Yeah, good one kid. *sob* Leave me alone.
Pft...Lorn has been cl...climbing up and down these mountains since...Forever.

replies.text: I saw his corpse. It wasn't a monster neither a falling.

message: No, no, no. The monsters...They did it! They killed my friends!!

replies.text: We'll talk later, when you be less drunken and nervous.
No, neither gornauds nor a falling killed him.

message: What then?!

replies.text: That's what I'm trying to figure out.
Nobody seems to know, or care about it.

message:
WHAT?! *hits the table and gets up* 

 Is that what we get in exchange of...?!

...these years...Uuugh.

[The smelly guy gets dizzy, sits down again next to the table and puts his head over his muscled arms]

replies.text: You seem tired. We'll talk later.

message: [The robust man is still tired and drunken, sat next to an unfinished jar of mead]

replies.text: Hey, don't drink anymore. I need you to get better.

message: And the g...guards?

replies.text: They considered it an accident and left it be.
The guards? Those lazy guys won't do anything.

message: Uuugh... I'm, I'm not. I drank too much mead. Day by day, since... since Kirg's dea...death.

replies.text: You'd better stop drinking. We talk later whenever you get better.
Is there something I can do?

message: M...Maybe some water. Yes, from the moun...tains. That'd be a relief!
You could get me some coo...cool water. Yes.
Do you mind bringing me a good and large bottle of water f...from the streams?

replies.text: No, go buy yourself a bottle.
Ok, I'll be back with the water.

message: Yes, East of he..re. There's a hole. Under the mountain side...

replies.text: Fine. I will come back with the water.

message: Uhmm, It's you... Have you brought the water?

replies.text: Here you are, a large bottle of fresh water.
Where could I find the streams?

message: I will be righ...right here, kid. Thank you.
Ag...Again?! East of here. Underground. Deep in those caverns.

replies.text: I'll bring the water, don't worry.

message: [A small natural pool has formed here. The water, emerging from small cracks in the rock, is cold and transparent]
[You fill the bottle with water]
[You fill another bottle]
[You fill a large bottle]

[The stout guy looks through the water you have brought to him. His eyes open widely. He starts to drink the water straight off and finishes in the blink of an eye, taking a deep breath just after putting the glass over the table]
Woah, I feel really good now.

replies.text: I'm glad to see you're better.

message: A reward? Isn't the satisfaction of aiding a lost soul enough reward?

replies.text: I can see you're much better.

message: And all thanks to you! Tell me, what did you need?

replies.text: Anything you could tell me about Lorn and his partners. That'd be fine.
I'll tell you later. I have things to do now.

message: HA, HA! Such a pity! But weren't you here to ask me something?

replies.text: Yes. People told me Lorn was a regular in this tavern.

message: Have a good day then. I surely will!
I see...
Well, I was part of a patrol crew formed by five people. Kamelio, Kirg, Duala, Lorn and me.
Mountain patrol crews were created because of the monster activity. Some people still think they are somehow sent by the people from Blackwater Settlement...

replies.text: No. They are suffering a siege for even more powerful monsters.

message: I know! We faced white wyrms on the mountain heights. I'm afraid political problems is something leaders of each place must deal with. We at least tried to keep Prim safe from monster attacks.
And that is not true. Or would they send monsters to their own dominion? Of course they wouldn't. There are monsters up there in the mountain heights too, possibly even more dangerous than gornauds.
We tried to keep the threat in the mountains, but gornauds invaded mountain wolves' homes and forced them to establish in the small fir forest around Prim.
But since the gornauds invaded the mountain sides, wolves went down to the fir forest and the path between Prim and the Elm mine got more and more unsafe.
Attacks by wolves got more and more frequent. While we were taking care of the gornauds, miners died by packs of wolves.

Several miners were killed by the wolves, so the mine eventually closed. Furthermore, the main mining tunnel between Elm mine and Stoutford collapsed and the relations with Blackwater Settlement tensed up.
Obviously, the mine had to close. Days after that, the tunnel that lead to Stoutford through the mountain collapsed and people from Blackwater Settlement blamed Prim.
Finally, like if a mastermind were behind all of this, a coordinated group of gornauds moved towards Prim from the East.
We got rid of them, but at what cost...
One of those beasts...Squashed Kirg's head with a single blow. We were...are always underestimating their intelligence.
I got severly injured when the mysterious disappearings started. The mine was the first place when it occurred. But then, some villagers disappeared too.
Gornauds are smart, but kidnapping people?

replies.text: Hmm, you have a point there.

message: Why would they?
Lorn must have discovered something. Just a week or two ago we were right here bantering and chatting, trying to forget that horrible scene of Kirg's death.

replies.text: Why didn't you come along with them?

message: Yes, someone behind the attacks and the following disappearings.
I was too afflicted. Lorn thought I was not gonna focus in the exploration...

replies.text: Did the mention anything at the tavern?
Where Lorn's crew started looking for the missing couple?

message: No, I don't think so. He was so drunk, and me too! \n We passed the whole night singing, chatting, forgetting...
What couple? I know nothing about a couple.

replies.text: A guy called Ehrenfest told me that was the mission.
I heard they were looking for a missing couple.

message: They went to the mountain side, just another patrol round...Who told you that?

replies.text: Never mind. I really need to go.
A guy called Ehrenfest said that to me.

message: Ehrenfest? Who is he? What does he know? It's public domain guard patrols are not actively searching missing villagers due to lack of resources.

replies.text: So he lied to me? Why?
Uhm...I will ask him about this incoherence.

message: Look, you should leave this be, maybe this is too shady for a kid like you.

replies.text: I will discover the whole truth about this.
I'm determined to solve this, once for all.
A couple of Gornauds aren't a problem for me. Why a thin man would?

message: If that is your determination, I will not interfere. You're valiant, kid!

replies.text: Things need to be cleared out. Bye.

message: Hah! *holds up the empty mead jar* I'm pretty sure of that, but beware anyway!

replies.text: Shadow be with you, my drunken friend.

message: This is no joke, OK? If that guy has really something to do with the missing people or Lorn's death, He won't surely be just a "thin man".

replies.text: I'll keep that in mind. Thank you.

message: You are right, but I didn't lie.
Remember while you were asking for Lorn, I asked some villagers precisely about that missing couple.

replies.text: I'm not going to hear your stories anymore.
What I remember is you, telling me about that missing couple.

message: $playername, I'm not lying!

replies.text: Again, you did. I cannot trust you.
I can't be sure of that.

message: I won't try to convince you. Now you must decide whether helping me or not. I won't ask twice, so make a choice wisely.

replies.text: I don't trust you. I will find my own way to solve this.
I'll think about it. See you soon.
Ok, I will help you. Let's solve this once for all.

message:
I see...Good luck, you'll need it.

[Ehrenfest walks slowly out of the room]

replies.text: You're still being shady, uh. Goodbye.

message: It is, It will.
Excellent. Let's share what we found out then.

replies.text: You're already aware of my information.

message: It's time to put things in common.

replies.text: You are already aware of my information.

message: Hasn't anybody said anything else?
Then, I've been the lucky one this time.
Both villagers and guards seemed pretty uneasy when I asked about the Feygard soldiers' presence.
I just confirmed my suspicion.
Are you sure?

replies.text: Yes. Please, tell me what you've discovered.

message: I strongly believe they're related with the disappearings.

replies.text: That seems to be taken with a grain of salt.

message: Put it this way. A weakened Prim will be easier to control. Although Lord Geomyr theorically reigns over the whole land, both isolated and southern lands have more independence.
It is well known there is an ancient chamber dedicated to worship the Shadow, which is probably Lord Geomyr's most powerful threat.
This is our best bet. I think we'd have to act before it's too late.
That Feygard general said he was gonna climb up the mountain. We should follow him up to Blackwater Settlement and stop him.

replies.text: Stop him? You mean killing him?
I'll love getting rid of that Feygard scum.

message: Excellent, excellent! I will lead the way, meet me at Blackwater Settlement. Beware of the monsters.

replies.text: Same to you, those scared monsters will make way to me.

message: What else could we do?

replies.text: Never mind, killing him is the safest choice.

message: Are you crazy or something? He would never talk to commoners like us!

replies.text: We will never know if we don't try.
You're right. It'll be better to get rid of him as soon as possible.
You're the insane guy here, thinking we can beat a group of elite trained soldiers.

message: I think you need some time to think about it.
[You hear noises and steps coming from the cabin]
*cough*, *cough* What the... *cough*. Go back home kid, quick. This place is *cough*, dangerous.

replies.text: Where can I find general Ortholion?
Gonna rest here first, sweet dreams.

message: What? What do you have to do with *cough*, him?

replies.text: [Lie]I have an important message to deliver him. It comes from Prim.
Never mind, what happened to you?

message: We were on the way to Blackwater Settlement, when we *cough*, *cough*, were attacked by a group of white wyrms. I got, uh, somewhat injured... So my general decided I should wait right here, safe from the monsters.

replies.text: Hope you get better. I must leave.
Ok. That's everything I need to know.
Feygard scum... Are you always such bigmouths? [Kill him]

message: I don't *cough*, think anybody would be that crazy to send a kid to a place like this. \n Sorry, *cough*, I don't have energy for holding up nonsense.
Thank you, thank *cough* you.
[The scout is sleeping on the ground. His wounds don't seem to be that bad]
What do you mean? *cough*
Wh..*cough* NO! \n [You manage to land a fatal blow to the already wounded soldier. Once you're sure she's dead, you set her body aside, out of the cabin]
I should check out the cabin first.
Hah! What about the shady guy you mentioned?

replies.text: I no longer collaborate with him.
He would only slow me down.
He seems a good man, but he lied to me.

message: I guess that's a wise choice, so what's your plan?

replies.text: I...really don't know where to start.
Do you have anything more to tell me about Lorn?

message: You sure? Ha ha, you're a kid after all!

replies.text: Can you tell me anything more about Lorn's latest mission?

message: Hmm. Liars can be good guys too, but why lying on that? I hope not to have any future business with him!

replies.text: Do you remember anything more about Lorn's last mission?

message:
Oh, c'mon. 

Then what about beating up these guards? They didn't move a finger for my friend, and I won't forget that.

replies.text: Sounds a bad idea, but let's do it.
I don't like to cause trouble.

message: Hmm, not really. But we could surely ask in the guardhouse. I very well know they will talk. They better be!
*laughs loudly*
Ha, ha! Never mind.

replies.text: Do you remember anything more about Lorn's mission?

message: Good! I am eager to crush some meatheads!
Oh, c'mon...

replies.text: Uh, and then I am the kid, right? Let's go.

message:
*crush* WHAT THE HELL JERN?!

[A fight is happening inside, better to hurry up]
Zzz... Zzz...

C'mon! Dare to raise your sword!

You! You left my partners DIE!

Stop, ok?! I'm really sorry, Jern! *sheathes his sword*

We were scared. That's all, ok?! Gornauds have been decimating us while you were in the tavern day and night.
Ah! Now your incompetence is my fault?

*raises his hands* Drop it already! 

We're getting more and more surrounded by those beasts, you know? Right now there's no point on worrying about somebody who fell off the mountain!
Are you out of your mind? Lorn would never ever died by something like that!
How can you be so sure? Accidents occur! He could have fallen off during an attack or a rock slide.

This is what the guy who reported it told me, too! 

Now I'm starting to welcome those Feygard guys. There aren't attacks anymore since they guard the village.
Eh?! What Feyga...
*stares at you* What the hell kid? Why're you here again?
Hey, show some respect. This youngster dared to go where you didn't. He told me what happened, too.
*puts an exhaustion face* Whatever...I neither know his name. Just another one of the very few visitors we receive here. He was wearing a blue cloak, I think.
The shady guy, isn't it?
This is serious. That guy might be behind the disappearings.

replies.text: He has been in the mine during these days.

message: We should look after him. This Ehrenfest guy needs to clear up many things.

We're short of men, and we don't even know where he is right now.

*Jern stares at you in the meanwhile*

replies.text: I can't be of help this time...

message: Or maybe yes.
Do you remember anything out of normal?

replies.text: He's been shady since the very beginning.
No...Apart from the need of not being heard by the Feygard soldiers.

message: Anything more specific?

replies.text: Give me some time to remember.
Umm...No, but I think he was scared of Feygard soldiers hearing our conversation.

message: Don't worry, We'll talk later.
I see...Feygard soldiers.
Seeking for their help seems not to be the worst idea right now.
That's right. But I feel that's what they wanted since the very beginning.
$playername, what do you think? This is probably our best bet.

replies.text: I'm gonna rest some time. See you later.
I will warn the general then.

message: It's settled then. We will spread the word among the guards.
$playername, you must reach Blackwater Settlement get help from General Ortholion.
Hmmm... Hmmm....

replies.text: Hey! I need to talk with the general, now!
Step aside, lowly minion. I have business with your boss.

message: [The scout stares at you wich an inconmensurable anger. Before you can react, she swings her dagger, opening a wound in your arm]

replies.text: How you dare?! Prepare to die, Feygard scum.

message: [A slim girl stands in front of you. Her armor seems to be made from leather, but it seems to rigid, like frozen, just like her face. The Feygard coat of arms gleams in her suit, but it's overshadowed by her eyes, nailed in you]
[You hear steps up in the mountain. It seems a Feygard soldier is guarding the cave entrance. General Ortholion must have already reached Blackwater Settlement]
So you have come this far just to get rid of me...
The crimes you have commited must be punished!

Hmmm... What crimes, evil creature?

Or you even dared to think you had a chance to trick a general of the glorious Feygard?!

I'm... *stares at you* 

$playername! It's time to end with all of this!
My lord... A kid? You come with a kid accusing me of something I never heard about?
[Just before starting to launch any attack, General Ortholion moves and disarms you with a single blow]
Ok, you bothered me more than I am willing to abide. Blackwater Settlement guards will take care of you.

replies.text: These guards are no match for...

message:
Bah! This is enough. $playername, weren't you so strong?! Pathetic.

You only had to distract him and take the blame!

replies.text: Hah. I always knew you were too much shady to be a good guy.

message: [Just before starting to launch any attack, General Ortholion moves and disarms you with a single blow]

Ortholion! How much is your life worth? Hoy many people?

Prove the honor of your glorious land. Come face me alone! No guards, no witnesses.

[Ehrenfest leaps unnaturally high, passing above me, and disappears in the blink of an eye]
I hoped someone else would take blame of this. But don't worry, soon we would be unstoppable.

replies.text: Do you always talk that much, liar?

message: *unsheathes his sword* Well, enough talk. I won't ignore your threats, evil creature.

replies.text: Ehrenfest, you have many things to explain!

message:
[People from the tavern start looking at the place where Ortholion and Ehrenfest were about to have a fight]

*looks around* No...Not yet. Argh! You kid, betrayer! You are about to discover how wrong you have chosen!

[The general tries to land a strike on Ehrenfest, but he just cuts a piece of his cloak. Ehrenfest is gone]

Hmpf...

replies.text: I thought Feygard generals were faster swinging their blades.

message: Look, I don't have time for you, but I don't kill kids, not yet. So step aside.

replies.text: I'm here to inform you about Ehrenfest. He's probably behind some disappearings in Prim.

message: You mean that weakling is responsible of those missing people from Prim of whom I've been informed recently?

replies.text: Weakling? Haven't you seen how he escaped?

message: Nothing impressive. Loyal followers of the Shadow have their tricks, just as I have my own.

replies.text: The Shadow? Do you believe in that?
Hope those tricks are better than your chasing abilities.

message: It's definitely something off with him. Another Shadow fanatic to get rid of, tsch.

replies.text: Shadow fanatic? Do you know him?

message: *laughs quietly* Only simple minds would see things as black or white. Whether I believe or not, people do, and we in Feygard keep that in mind.

replies.text: ...Ok, now that you're aware of the situation, I'd better leave.
What about "I don't have time to..."?

message: I have no time for this absurd talk. I must be sure this guy's road ends in the Elm mine.
No. But It's quite obvious by the way he accused me.

replies.text: And what will you do, general slowness?
Well, this is not really my problem. Bye.

message: Hmm...Maybe. You came up this far after all. Go warn my soldiers. They are settled in the tunnel entrance, South of Prim.

replies.text: This is getting too complicated. I'd better leave.
I bet they'll pay attention to a kid like me, right?

message: Not so fast. Seeing that you reached this place but my scouts couldn't, I think you will be of use.

replies.text: What if I don't want to help you?

message: Then I'll oficially accuse you of betray and murder intent against a Feygard general. I'll bring you to Feygard and you will never see your family again.

replies.text: How you dare?! Prepare to die!

message:
*starts laughing after landing you to the ground effortlessly* 

Look, take this signet. With this, my soldiers settled outside the mining tunnel entrance will believe in your words. Tell them I went to the Elm mine.

replies.text: Ok, ok. I will but please don't hurt me anymore.

message: Take this, and show it to the soldiers settled on the mining tunnel entrance. Tell them I went to the Elm mine.
Are you still here?! Go, go now!

replies.text: Someday you will regret your manners...

message: Hey! You alright?

replies.text: *shows the signet* your general has gone to Elm mine. He could be in trouble.

message: Yeah, sure. We are here settled by command of General Orhtolion of Feygard. You have no business here.

replies.text: *shows the signet* Yeah, sure. Now hurry up! Your general is waiting for you in the Elm mine.

message: *shouts* Hey, slackers! You're moving now. It's an order. Prepare yourselves, we are going to the Elm mine, general needs us!
I'll lead the way. Thank you kid, now go back to the village. It's safer there.

replies.text: Be careful, I heard mountain wolves are a trouble for Feygard soldiers.

message: Hey, do you know what's happening here? These serious-looking soldiers entered the mine without permission.

replies.text: They're soldiers of Feygard. I come along them, don't worry.

message: You'd better telling me the truth. I will report it later.

replies.text: Have you seen a guy with a cloak over here?

message: I was taking a break in the beds over there, so no idea, sorry. No one usually comes here but you and those...Noisy soldiers.

replies.text: Don't worry, we won't cause much trouble.

message: [There's a horrid smell inside that passage. On top of that, it's completely dark]
[Fortunately, the torch is still burning, but unfortunately, the passage is still collapsed]
[Another pitch black tunnel. This one has an old, consumed torch in the wall]

replies.text: Replace it for a burning torch.

message: [A weak fire illuminates the place. The tunnel is collapsed, but there are some trinkets and clothes on the floor]
[This corpse is not old. It is probably one of the missing miners. He has a single large wound in his chest]
You've already checked this corpse.
[Yet another corpse of a miner. This one seems to have been killed during job]

replies.text: May the shadow be with your soul.

message: [After a few seconds, you feel a little dumb talking with a corpse and leave]
[Everything seems too old and stinky to be worth a penny, but after half a minute of search you see a strange pendant behind miner's shirt]

replies.text: I need to take a bath.

message: [This hole's smell is particular. The floor is limp, and you can see a bunch of olm larvae there. Searching here doesn't worth it]

[The passage in front of you isn't dark enough to ignore the constant dripping of the walls, limp and deformed. For some reason, animals don't get closer to you as you get closer to the tunnel, which is surprising and worrying at the same time]
Sssssh...

replies.text: Hey, have you seen my brother Andor?

message: Hey kid! You shouldn't be here, there are dangerous animals.

replies.text: Are you scared of the snakes?

message: Eh? No. We are...Uhm, keeping the rearguard safe. After all, this is the mine only entrance.

replies.text: Yeah, sure. See you later, cowards.

message: Our... mighty general has already caught that Shadow fanatic...Yes. Deep in the mine that's where he is. He's coming back...Probably.

replies.text: Aha, so no idea. Thanks anyway.
Good. Gonna check that out, bye.

message: *looks nervous* Kid! Go back now, it's really dangerous past here.

replies.text: Come with me, we'll cover each other's back.
Can you clear me the way then?

message: No way! I have a home to come back you know? And you probably too.

replies.text: Step aside then, you're on my way.

message:
*stares at the tunnels* They're dark, stinky, and narrow. We were going to pass in line through them.

But seconds after the other scout entered, an horrible scream came from inside there... It was him, I'm sure!
...I ran away. I am sure there's something dangerous inside there. Really dangerous! Dangerous enough to make a Feygard soldier scream that way.

replies.text: It was surely a cave rat. I will find out now.

message:
We...We haven't seen him. The other scout entered the tunnel... *looks back*

Two men are guarding the rearback. Something's off with this place.

replies.text: I will look for him, bye.

message: [There was a tunnel entrance here, but a landslide brought it down]
HAH! I SPOTTED YOU, EVIL BEING! *raises his sword*

replies.text: This one won't be my fault.
Hah! I spotted you, useless soldier!

message: [Something horrible has happened in this mine. Did Ehrenfest do all of this?]
[There's blood all over the wall! It's like something threw this guy against it with an enormous force. Unfortunately, there's nothing to plunder here]
You wouldn't sleep here.
[This large chest is locked with a simple but robust lock with a small keyhole in its center]
[Despite the rust, you introduce the key in the lock without major trouble. It results to fit well enough. The chest is now open]
[The chest stays inmutable]
You cannot read the sign from here.

MINERS: this zone has been declared unstable. No further excavations must be done here.

Signed by Guthbered of Prim.
[The floor collapses below you, and you fall onto a muddy terrain]

replies.text: Ugh, never thought I was gonna get so dirty.

message: [The scarce vegetation here, mostly moss, is strangely glued to that orange glowing ore]

[When you get your fingers closer to the moss, it somehow turns to dust. Your finger gets glued to the seemingly solid ore, but you rapidly take it off from there. It's not a serious injury, but you feel like that ore has taken away part of your life essence]
[You try to use a pickaxe you grabbed earlier, but it obviously breaks due to its excessive rust]
[You get tired after a few strikes; the ore is still there]
[After some minutes of intense mining you finally get a gem and put it in a safe pocket in your backpack]
You have already mined here.
[There was a hole in the floor just below you and the rails. You stumble upon a crossbar and flat on your face, making the rails break]
[He is no longer breathing]
[You try to put off the armor first but you soon discover both the man and the armor itself are covered by that glowing ore. You instantly stop grabbing it. The glowing ore is somehow growing]
[From the soldier you met inside here, only dust remains]
Wh... *cough* ...at the heck?! *cough*, *cough*, *cough* Kid, go away. This thing... *cough*, *cough*... GO AWAY!

*ignoring you*... You idiot kid... *cough*. It's a trap, THE WHOLE THING *cough*, *cough* is...

...This mine is... cur...
[There's some water dripping from the crack on the wall. Its sound is relaxing. You also hear a flow of water near you. This part of the mine hasn't been much explored]

replies.text: Pour some water into a small vial.

message: [You patiently wait for the vial to be filled by the few water drops on the wall]
[When the vial is half filled you realise its more mud than water. You discard the vial]
[There is a poor walled up passage behind these planks. This specific table was recently removed and put back. General might have passed through here]

[Once you pull off the wooden board a cold breeze leaks out from the dark corridor. A few seconds later, you hear multiple cracks on the ceiling. More of that glowing ore is growing in front of you...And it's getting closer!]

replies.text: Argh! I'm getting tired of this glowing thing.

message: The animated debris is blocking the way.

The sign reads: 

– DO NOT THROW ITEMS TO THE POOL.
– DO NOT SPLASH.
– RELAX.

Signed by Guthbered of Prim.
[This chest has no keyhole. It may be worth taking a quick peek inside]
[You try to open the chest but the lid is stuck]
[The lid is still stuck]
[You try pulling the lid again with all your strength. The chest finally tips over and all of its content gets dropped on the floor]
Be quiet.
Look *points to the large crystals*...It grows.
Psst! No, don't leave! Come here, quick!
Unbelievable...

replies.text: Uhm, whatever. I have to go.

message: General...Oh! That's right. I don't think this is the right way.

This no longer seems to be part of the Elm mine. Look at all these strange creatures... 

Uh, I'm the only one that have gone this far. My partners must have discovered the right path.

replies.text: Half of your partners are dead and the other half are too scared to even going inside the mine.
I haven't seen any other way. This is the right one.

message: You sure?
Where are my partners then?

replies.text: They were all consumed by those crystals you were amazed with.

message: That cannot be... Damn it! I knew those screams were not from these creatures.

replies.text: Save your breath. We still have a mission, and monsters to slay.

message: But...Ugh, you're dead right. Soliders of Feygard MUST NOT SHRINK FROM DANGER!
Yes...
No, It's not your fault. You could have done nothing.

Ok...You're strong and valiant, but are you reliable enough?

I will go all the way back and call for reinforcements. I want you to explore this cavern. If you find something too dangerous, please return to the mine, will you?

replies.text: That was my plan until you distracted me.
Anything for the glory of Feygard!

message:
I knew I could count on you!

This sign of bravery won't be forgotten.

replies.text: Whatever, step aside I'm leading the way!

message: [The Feygard soldier you were trying to ignore wawes his hands brusquely, like warning you from some inminent danger]
Will you help me or not?

I will leave this place right now and come back with more men anyway!

Kids these days...Annoying.
The path is blocked in this direction.
[A couple of fences don't let you exit the tunnel this way. This place is clearly out of Elm mine's extension, who else has been here?]
The cage is locked.
This pool is deeper than it seemed from further distance. You cannot swim.
The battle has already started. Iluminated by the orangish glow of the crystals, Ortholion steps towards Ehrenfest, slowly making him retreat to the border of the hill.
This is the end, evil being! Surrender now!
*puts hands on his head* Oh?
Me? Are you referring to me? *starts laughing uncontrollably*
Cut it out! For your crimes commited against the people and the kingdom of Feygard I sentence you...

TO DIE!!!

*Orhtolion throws his sword directly to Ehrenfest's chest*

Wh...What...

*Ehrenfest emits a brilliant flash of orangish light from his eyes, and the sword suddenly stops its way towards him, remaning suspended in the midair*
W...Woah! This is impressive. *opens his arms and looks to his hands* To think one or two weeks ago I would have died against a gornaud... This is really impres...!

In the blink of an eye, Ortholion approaches Ehrenfest and draws his second sword. When the general is about to rapidly sever Ehrenfest's head, he reacts grabbing Ortholion's hand. 

Desperately, Ortholion tries to let his hand go, but It's Ehrenfest who stops grabbing and takes advantage of the moment to land a tremendous kick on the general's chest, unbelievably denting his armor and bouncing him against the wall. The sword falls to the ground, and Ehrenfest takes it.

Interesting...So you hypocrites use weapons you yourself ban. Ha, ha! *coughs* 

Uh...What's wrong with me...I'm sorry general, but you're no longer valuable. Why hunting a sheep when you can own the flock? 

*keeps staring at the sword, handling it with ease.*
The kick was such brutal Ortholion fell unconscious.
Hmm... $playername, I wonder how your brother Andor would react if he knew I had to kill you.

replies.text: What do you know about him?!
So you're the guy whom Lodar told me about.
I won't hear your lies. I'll finish you right here.

message:
Only if you were stronger...Maybe I could convince you to join us, *cough* but I have to admit my plan was blaming you of Ortholion's death.

You know, we're tired of you asking questions here and there, *cough* *cough*.
Lodar, right. He sins of double moraility! His poisons killed hundreds, but he prefered to hide in that dirty forest and elude any responsibility like a retired farmer.

No you won't, sorry. 

My mission is done here. It was done weeks ago, but I...Someone decided I should stay and draw Feygard's attention here.
Don't look at me that way, kid...*laughs*. This is too complicated for a young mind.

How tetchy! The guards I tortured eventually understood my words... 

Maybe you should try that orangish substance too.

Ehrenfest jumps off the cliff, sinking in the dark streams, leaving you in the middle of a word.

You soon begin to hear steps. Someone's comming, might be the reinforcements?
Hello, unfortunate soul. I'm Kamelio.

replies.text: Kamelio? You are one of those missing people in Prim!
Jern will be glad you're alright.
I need your help! There's a man lying unconscious there.

message: Ah...Yes. Don't worry, yo go first. *approaches you*
Alright? My body has not seen better days. But that drunkard will never get to know it.
*approaching you* He's not going to see you alive again.
Yes. Lorn, Duala and me were caught and tortured. Lorn... He spat everything out like the coward he was.
That guy you were talking to before.

replies.text: Ehrenfest! What has he done to you?!

message: Everything. From where the shirne was to how to enter and pass through the pitch black tunnels.

Escape? When the torturer came back, he behaved totally different. He freed us and brought us some food and recovery potions. Since then, I feel like I have reborn!

All my injuries were cured, and my mind was set free. Now I know the truth, and what I must do.

replies.text: You're starting to sound very murky. I'd better leave and seek help,

message:
He just wanted to know where an old shirne location. And I forgive him everything. He came back and freed Duala and me and gave us food and a marvelous elixir he called "recovery potion".

Now my body is reborn and my mind is set free. I know what's wrong and what's right, and I know what I must do.

replies.text: What do you have to do?

message: Not so fast. My mind is clear, you need to die now along that Feygard scum.

replies.text: Oh? Let's see if you can stand a single blow!
This hatred against Feygard is injuring you; I'll be your cure.

message: Killing you first, then killing the guy over there. That's it.

replies.text: Ok, you're completely out of your mind.
Killing me? How you dare, die!

message: Uhm... What a thwack. $playername, where's the...

...Oh. Alright, we will chat later. Now we're going out of he...

Watch out!

replies.text: Hmpf, I will kill you ten more times if needed.

message: Tsch, you cannot lose! I'm still recovering.
